questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 μm3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a heterogeneous group of mutations, all of which lead to deficits in DNA repair mechanisms and, thus, a high frequency of chromosomal aberrations. Fanconi anemia has a wide variety of clinical manifestations. One of the most common and notable features is a predisposition for developing acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndromes in early adulthood. Pancytopenia is also common and manifests with mucocutaneous bleeding, recurrent infections, and anemia (normocytic or macrocytic). Other skin, skeletal, and organ anomalies include short stature, hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation of the skin, cafe-au-lait spots, microcephaly and developmental delay, ocular abnormalities (e.g., esotropia and hypertelorism), and thumb and forearm malformations.

Fanconi anemia should not be confused with Fanconi syndrome, a proximal renal tubular defect resulting in type 2 renal tubular acidosis (Type II RTA) and defective reabsorption of, e.g., potassium, glucose, phosphate, and amino acids.

B) INCORRECT:

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), an X-linked disorder caused by a mutation in the WAS protein, is characterized by eczema, bleeding diathesis, and recurrent infections. Although WAS may cause thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, it is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection in children can cause anemia due to aplastic crisis and may also lead to mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. However, parvovirus B19 infection is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

D) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by a defect in a cell membrane protein leading to hemolysis and venous thromboembolism. Hemolysis leads to jaundice, anemia, and, in some cases, end-organ damage. Although pancytopenia is consistent with the present case, the absence of jaundice or other signs of hemolysis makes PNH unlikely. PNH is also not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia and neurological defects such as paresthesias and sensory ataxia. It is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

F) INCORRECT:

About 60% of cases of pediatric immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) occur within a few weeks of a viral infection. Postviral ITP is generally a self-limiting condition that does present with thrombocytopenia, as in this case, but does not involve a decreased leukocyte count or anemia. Rather than the hyperpigmentation and cafe-au-lait spots seen here, the skin changes associated with ITP are petechiae that may coalesce into larger purpura and ecchymoses.

G) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy. Although this patient has some features of ALL (infections, anemia, and thrombocytopenia), the absence of other symptoms of ALL, e.g., bone pain, fever, and lymphadenopathy, makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, ALL is not classically associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.
questions.hint: This patient with pancytopenia, short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, and strabismus most likely has Fanconi anemia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for evaluation of several bruises on her lower extremities. She has had these bruises for about 6 weeks, and her mother is concerned that she might be being bullied at school. The patient has had increasing fatigue and pallor over the past several days. She has a history of recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures treated with carbamazepine. She appears pale and ill. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with no organomegaly. There are several subcutaneous purple spots on her legs bilaterally. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2600/mm3, platelet count is 18,000/mm3, and reticulocyte count is 0.3%. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP) causes palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy), arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, renal disease, and/or possibly anemia (as a result of gastrointestinal bleeding). Although this patient presents with anemia and petechiae, her thrombocytopenia and lack of other features are inconsistent with HSP.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a syndrome that is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia. Although it is often asymptomatic, it may also manifest with easy bruising or possibly spontaneous petechiae. However, it does not cause pancytopenia or signs of anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common initial symptom of sickle cell disease (SCD) is acute and chronic pain in any body part, which is caused by a vaso-occlusive crisis. Further features include anemia, bone pain, growth retardation, and infections. The onset of SCD is most commonly at 4–5 months of age. Other than anemia, none of these features apply to this adolescent girl.

D) INCORRECT:

Although SLE may cause anemia, thrombocytopenia, fatigue, and easy bruising, it would also typically manifest with fever, malar rash, myalgia, and/or arthritis, none of which are present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Certain agents (remember “Can't Make New Blood Cells Properly:” Carbamazepine, Methimazole, NSAIDs, Benzenes, Chloramphenicol, Propylthiouracil) can induce bone marrow failure and subsequent aplastic anemia. Treatment consists of cessation of the causative agent and supportive therapy (i.e., blood or platelet transfusion, treatment of infections).

F) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) causes thrombocytopenic purpura, neurologic abnormalities, fever, renal disease, and hemolytic anemia. Hematologic findings of TTP include hematuria, schistocytes, decreased Hb, elevated LDH, elevated reticulocytes, and thrombocytopenia. Although this patient presents with pancytopenia and its sequelae, she is much younger than the typical age of onset (approx. 40 years) and does currently not have neurologic abnormalities or renal disease, making TTP very unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's easy bruising, fatigue, and pallor, combined with pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia) and decreased reticulocyte count, indicates aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-day history of fever and bleeding after brushing his teeth. His mother also reports that her son has asked to be picked up early from soccer practice the past few days because of fatigue. He appears pale and ill. His temperature is 38.3°C (101.1°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with no organomegaly. There are several spots of subcutaneous bleeding on the abdomen and shins. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2000/mm3, a platelet count of 40,000/mm3, and a reticulocyte count of 0.2%. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. A bone marrow biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hypocellular fat-filled marrow with normal RBC morphology
Hypercellular, dysplastic bone marrow with ringed sideroblasts
Infiltration of the marrow with collagen and fibrous tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sheets of abnormal plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy are indicative of multiple myeloma. Although multiple myeloma can also manifest with pancytopenia, it typically occurs in older patients (peak incidence 50–70 years) and is usually associated with additional findings such as bone pain and hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow specimen (H&E stain)

Plasma cells are large cells that typically have an eccentric nucleus (hatched overlay) with dense, clumped chromatin. The cytoplasm is deeply basophilic due to the abundance of rough endoplasmic reticulum required for the synthesis of antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Normocellular bone marrow is unlikely in this patient, as anemia, reticulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytopenia suggest bone marrow insufficiency.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of spongy bone (H&E stain, 350x magnification)

A trabecula (dark pink) extends through the spongy bone from the left edge across the lower portion of the image. The trabecula is surrounded by several hematopoietic elements (purple) that make up the red marrow. Dispersed throughout the red marrow are adipocytes (white) that comprise the yellow marrow.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy findings of hypocellular fat-filled marrow with normal RBC morphology are characteristic of aplastic anemia; hypocellularity indicates decreased production of all blood cells (i.e., bone marrow insufficiency). Aplastic anemia is most commonly idiopathic but can also be caused by medications (e.g., carbamazepine, NSAIDs), radiation, or viruses (e.g., parvovirus B19). It may also be hereditary (e.g., Fanconi anemia) or a preleukemic condition. Bone marrow biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other important differential diagnoses such as myelofibrosis or a hematological malignancy with bone marrow infiltration. Management of aplastic anemia involves treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., infection), if identifiable, as well as blood transfusions, immunosuppressive therapy, and hematopoietic cell transplantation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypercellular, dysplastic bone marrow with ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow biopsy is found in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). Although MDS can also manifest with pancytopenia and the resulting symptoms, it usually affects elderly patients or occurs secondary to an underlying condition (e.g., cytostatic therapy) and is often associated with hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, in contrast to this patient's condition, MDS usually progresses slowly.
Image Description:

Bone marrow smear in iron stain (Prussian blue): Excess of immature blasts (B) and presence of ringed sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are erythrocytes with iron-loaded (hence blue) mitochondria (arrows). The presence of ringed sideroblasts indicates ineffective erythropoiesis.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased bone marrow lymphoblast count would indicate acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with bone marrow infiltration. ALL often occurs in children and bone marrow infiltration due to ALL would cause anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, ALL is typically associated with leukocytosis on a CBC (due to immature leukocytes in peripheral blood), hepatosplenomegaly (due to tumor infiltration), and painless lymphadenopathy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bone marrow smear (H&E stain)

Multiple lymphoblasts, identifiable as large basophilic cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and a large round nucleus with clumpy chromatin and prominent nucleoli, can be seen. The presence of > 20% of lymphoblasts within a bone marrow smear is diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The cells surrounding the lymphoblasts are erythroid precursors, mature erythrocytes, and mature neutrophils.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the marrow with collagen and fibrous tissue is seen in conditions such as primary myelofibrosis and hairy cell leukemia. A dry tap is therefore often found on bone marrow aspiration. While both conditions can also manifest with pancytopenia and the resulting symptoms, they are more common in adults, and patients typically present with splenomegaly.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor), thrombocytopenia (e.g., petechiae, bleeding), and leukopenia (e.g., fever due to infection). Pancytopenia and reticulocytopenia in the absence of hepatosplenomegaly (no extramedullary hematopoiesis) suggest aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and frequent upper respiratory tract infections. She is at the 2nd percentile for height and 10thpercentile for weight. Physical examination shows pallor, diffuse hyperpigmented macules, absence of the radial bones, and hypoplastic thumbs. Her hemoglobin concentration of 8.7 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2,500/mm3, and platelet count is 30,000/mm3. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a defect in a gene encoding a protein that is normally involved in which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mechanisms of mismatch repair are defective in hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer. However, patients with this syndrome are typically asymptomatic in childhood and manifest with symptoms of colorectal cancer (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding, abdominal pain) in adulthood. This syndrome is not associated with short stature, pancytopenia, or congenital abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Defects in the excision of pyrimidine dimers (a type of nucleotide excision repair) are associated with xeroderma pigmentosum. This condition causes extreme photosensitivity and the development of multiple precancerous lesions that can progress to skin cancer early in childhood. It is not associated with pancytopenia, short stature, or congenital anomalies.

C) INCORRECT:

Defects in the hydrolysis of glucocerebroside cause Gaucher disease. The buildup of glucocerebroside in the bone marrow can lead to pancytopenia, but Gaucher disease does not cause short stature, café-au-lait spots, absent radial bones, or hypoplastic thumbs. In addition, the patient does not have other features of Gaucher disease such as bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, osteoporosis, or aseptic necrosis of the femoral head.

D) CORRECT:

Fanconi anemia results from a mutation in the genes that encode proteins that are responsible for homologous recombination of DNA interstrand crosslinks. Breast and ovarian cancers with BRCA1 mutation are also caused by a defect in homologous end joining repair.

E) INCORRECT:

Defects in maturation of erythroid progenitor cells cause Diamond-Blackfan anemia. This condition manifests with short stature and pallor but typically causes pure red cell aplasia, not pancytopenia. While patients can have congenital abnormalities, Diamond-Blackfan anemia is associated with triphalangeal thumbs, not hypoplastic thumbs. Additionally, this condition manifests very early in childhood (typically before 1 year of age).

F) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 results from defects in the NF1 gene, which normally inhibits the Ras signal transduction pathway and prevents cell growth and proliferation. Although café-au-lait spots are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, the patient does not have other typical features of the disease such as Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, or optic gliomas. Additionally, this condition is not associated with pancytopenia, short stature, absent radial bones, or hypoplastic thumbs.
questions.hint: This girl's pancytopenia (which results in fatigue and recurrent infections), short stature, hyperpigmented macules (café-au-lait spots), and congenital anomalies (e.g., absent radial bones, hypoplastic thumbs) are features that indicate a diagnosis of Fanconi anemia, an autosomal recessive bone marrow failure syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive daytime sleepiness and exertional dyspnea for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and several pinpoint, purple spots on his legs. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 3000/mm3, and platelet count is 16,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. Which of the following laboratory values is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transferrin concentration varies inversely to iron stores and is therefore increased in patients with iron deficiency anemia. This patient's peripheral blood smear shows no features of iron deficiency (e.g., microcytosis, hypochromasia). In addition, pancytopenia cannot be explained by iron deficiency alone. Instead, this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia in which iron stores, and thus transferrin concentrations, are typically normal. In some cases of aplastic anemia, iron stores may even be increased (due to lack of use) and transferrin levels decreased accordingly.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated homocysteine concentrations may be seen in vitamin B12 deficiency or folate deficiency. A deficiency of these vitamins can cause megaloblastic anemia and may even lead to pancytopenia. However, peripheral blood smear in patients with megaloblastic anemia typically shows macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils, not normochromic, normocytic cells.

C) INCORRECT:

The reticulocyte count can serve as a marker of effective erythropoiesis. An elevated reticulocyte count may be seen in cases of increased RBC breakdown or loss. As this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia, in which bone marrow activity is drastically reduced, his reticulocyte count would be decreased rather than increased.

D) CORRECT:

Clinical findings of fatigue, pallor, and petechiae (pinpoint, purple spots), together with laboratory results showing pancytopenia, are consistent with aplastic anemia. In patients with aplastic anemia, peripheral blood smear typically shows normocytosis or mild macrocytosis. An increase in erythropoietin (EPO) production (hypoxia-induced EPO expression) is a physiological response to anemia, as EPO stimulates erythropoiesis. Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure, which has a variety of causes, such as viruses, medication side effects, congenital etiologies, radiation, and toxins; > 50% of cases are idiopathic.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is a marker of cell breakdown. The combination of pancytopenia and increased LDH may be seen in conditions such as paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria or hematological malignancy (e.g., acute leukemia). However, these conditions typically also manifest with abnormal blood smear findings, such as signs of hemolysis (e.g., schistocytes) or malignancy (e.g., blast cells).
questions.hint: A bone marrow biopsy of this patient would most likely show hypocellular, fat-filled bone marrow, consistent with aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fatigue and bruises on her elbows. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with no organomegaly. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2000/mm3, a platelet count of 40,000/mm3, and a reticulocyte count of 0.2%. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. A bone marrow biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Infiltration of collagen and fibrous tissue
Wrinkled cells with a fibrillary cytoplasm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the marrow with collagen and fibrous tissue is seen in conditions such as primary myelofibrosis and hairy cell leukemia. A dry tap is therefore often found on bone marrow aspiration. While both conditions can also present with pancytopenia, patients typically present with hepatosplenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (reticulin stain; intermediate magnification)

The bone marrow is hypercellular (no fat cells left between hematopoietic cells) and shows a remarkable increase in reticulin fibers (stained black). There are several clusters of atypical megakaryocytes (green overlay). The trabecular bone appears thickened/sclerotic (red overlay).

This appearance is characteristic of myelofibrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sheets of abnormal plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy are indicative of multiple myeloma. Although multiple myeloma can also present with pancytopenia and the resulting symptoms, it is typically associated with additional features such as bone pain and hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow specimen (H&E stain)

Plasma cells are large cells that typically have an eccentric nucleus (hatched overlay) with dense, clumped chromatin. The cytoplasm is deeply basophilic due to the abundance of rough endoplasmic reticulum required for the synthesis of antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Wrinkled macrophages with a fibrillary cytoplasm are characteristic of Gaucher disease, which can present with pancytopenia. However, patients with Gaucher disease usually present during childhood, and other features such as hepatosplenomegaly, osteoporosis, and painful bone crises would be present.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear from a patient with bilateral femoral neck necrosis (PAS stain)

A large cell (yellow overlay) with an eccentric nucleus (green overlay) can be seen. The cytoplasm shows a striated pattern.

This is the typical appearance of a Gaucher cell, as seen in Gaucher disease.

D) CORRECT:

Hypocellular bone marrow with prominent fat spaces within (“empty marrow” appearance) is characteristic of aplastic anemia. This condition is most commonly idiopathic but can also be caused by medications (e.g., carbamazepine, NSAIDs), radiation, or viruses (e.g., parvovirus B19), may be inherited (e.g., Fanconi anemia), or occur as a preleukemic condition. Bone marrow biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other important differential diagnoses such as leukemia. Treatment of aplastic anemia involves treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., infection), if identifiable, as well as blood transfusions, immunosuppressive therapy, and hematopoietic cell transplantation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased number of myeloblasts in the bone marrow is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which would occur among adults and can cause anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, a CBC in patients with AML would usually show an increased total leukocyte count due to the presence of myeloblasts in peripheral blood.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear (Wright-Giemsa stain, high magnification)

Promyelocytes with azurophilic granules can be seen as well as a myeloblast containing multiple violet, rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, known as Auer rods (examples indicated by yellow lines).

Auer rods are typically seen in certain types of acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., APL) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypercellular, dysplastic bone marrow with ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow biopsy is found in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). Although MDS can also present with pancytopenia, it usually affects elderly patients or occurs secondary to an underlying condition (e.g., cytostatic therapy) and is often associated with hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, in contrast to this patient's condition, MDS usually progresses slowly.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of blood cells from a bone marrow sample (Prussian blue stain)

Image shows numerous mature and immature erythrocytes. Some of the immature RBCs feature round, basophilic inclusions (iron deposits; arrowhead) within their mitochondria (which mostly surround the nuclei). These cells are called sideroblasts (red overlay).

Sideroblasts are found in various diseases such as sideroblastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, and sickle cell disease.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory findings (i.e., fatigue due to anemia, bruising due to thrombocytopenia, and leukocytopenia) indicate pancytopenia with a decreased reticulocyte count. In the absence of splenomegaly, these findings indicate aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 5-day history of fever, fatigue, and red spots on her body. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101.1°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, petechiae, and a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2000/mm3, a platelet count of 40,000/mm3, and a reticulocyte count of 0.2%. Peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. A bone marrow aspirate shows hypocellularity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Aplastic anemia is the cause of this patient's pancytopenia, normocytic anemia, and hypocellularity on bone marrow aspirate. Viral infections, either idiopathic (i.e., nontypeable or unknown virus, as in this case), EBV, or CMV are known to cause aplastic anemia in otherwise healthy children. Noninfectious causes include drugs (e.g., chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, or benzene), prior radiation, congenital conditions (e.g., Fanconi anemia or Shwachman-Diamond syndrome), and complications of leukemia. Parvovirus B19 may also cause pure red cell aplasia or aplastic crisis, but these primarily occur in patients with immunodeficiency or chronic hemolytic anemias, respectively.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma classically manifests with signs of hypercalcemia (e.g., abdominal pain), renal impairment, anemia (e.g., shortness of breath, fatigue, or pallor), and bony lesions (CRAB criteria). Peripheral smear characteristically shows rouleaux formations, and marrow aspiration demonstrates abnormal populations of plasma cells. This condition is virtually unheard of in children, with a peak incidence in the 6th decade.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary myelofibrosis is a condition that is very rare in childhood, with a peak incidence between the 6th–7th decades. Labs can demonstrate pancytopenia and bone marrow hypocellularity, but the condition is chronic in nature and is often accompanied by splenomegaly. A peripheral smear would demonstrate nucleated erythrocyte precursors and immature myeloid cells. This young patient has both a different clinical course and a peripheral smear.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (reticulin stain; intermediate magnification)

The bone marrow is hypercellular (no fat cells left between hematopoietic cells) and shows a remarkable increase in reticulin fibers (stained black). There are several clusters of atypical megakaryocytes (green overlay). The trabecular bone appears thickened/sclerotic (red overlay).

This appearance is characteristic of myelofibrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an autoimmune disease targeting platelets, which results in thrombocytopenia and causes bleeding manifestations. In ITP, there are normal RBC and leukocyte counts, normochromic and normocytic cells on peripheral smear, and normal bone marrow findings. This patient's pancytopenia and hypocellular marrow would be inconsistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), occurring most commonly in children aged 2–5 years, manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and B symptoms. Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hyperleukocytosis are common laboratory abnormalities and peripheral smear typically shows granulocyte precursors and nucleated erythrocytes. Bone marrow aspirate would show hypercellularity owing to neoplastic invasion, not hypocellularity as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bone marrow smear (H&E stain)

Multiple lymphoblasts, identifiable as large basophilic cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and a large round nucleus with clumpy chromatin and prominent nucleoli, can be seen. The presence of > 20% of lymphoblasts within a bone marrow smear is diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The cells surrounding the lymphoblasts are erythroid precursors, mature erythrocytes, and mature neutrophils.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: This patient's history of acute fever, fatigue, and maculopapular rash is suggestive of a viral infection. Her lab values demonstrating pancytopenia in conjunction with a decreased reticulocyte count, normal peripheral smear, and bone marrow hypocellularity all likely stem from this infection.

questions.text:
A young man, 19 years of age, reports several months of dyspnea on exertion. He has occasional palpitations and dizziness with activity, as well as intermittent episodes of diffuse abdominal pain. He reports no chest pain, lower-extremity edema, and orthopnea. He has a history of portal-vein thrombosis, for which he received rivaroxaban for 6 months. He currently takes no medications.
Physical examination reveals regular tachycardia with a heart rate of 104 beats per minute, mild scleral icterus, no murmurs or gallops, clear lungs, no abdominal tenderness, no lower-extremity edema, and a normal skin assessment.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3000
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
40
40–70


Neutrophil count (per mm3)
1200
1900–7600



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
30
41–53


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
99
80–100



Platelet count (per mm3)
90,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
6.0
0.5–2.5



Haptoglobin (mg/dL)
<8
16–199


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.8–1.3


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
2.5
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.3
0.1–0.3



Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
472
100–190


Prothrombin time, partial-thromboplastin time, and D-dimer are within normal limits. A peripheral-blood smear reveals normal platelets, some macrocytic red cells, and polychromasia. Urinalysis shows 2 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and no leukocytes. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is unlikely, given the lack of schistocytes on peripheral-blood smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is unlikely, given the lack of spherocytes on peripheral-blood smear and the negative direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is unlikely, given the normal coagulation studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Although abdominal pain occurs with some forms of porphyria, the rest of the patient’s presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia, a history of portal-vein thrombosis, and pancytopenia together suggest a diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a rare, acquired bone-marrow disorder caused by mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan anchor gene, leading to the partial absence or complete absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol-linked proteins (e.g., CD55 and CD59) on blood cells. PNH cells are susceptible to complement-mediated lysis that occurs in the intravascular space and causes hemoglobinuria/hemosiderinuria and episodes of dark urine.

Thrombosis, the most common cause of death in patients with PNH, may occur in unusual sites. Some patients with PNH experience bone-marrow failure resulting in pancytopenia. PNH is associated with increased risk for myelodysplastic syndrome, aplastic anemia, and leukemia.

First-line therapy for hemolytic PNH is eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody against the complement protein C5.

Key learning point: The triad of the most prominent clinical features of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and pancytopenia.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman reports fatigue and abdominal discomfort for the past several months, as well as early satiety and 4.5 kg of unintended weight loss during the past 6 months. She states that she has had no fevers or night sweats. She was previously in excellent health.
On examination, the patient has a heart rate of 85 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 117/64 mm Hg. She exhibits conjunctival pallor but no palpable lymphadenopathy. No jugular venous distention is evident. Her lung examination is normal. Her spleen is palpated 14 cm below the left costal margin, and her liver is palpated 8 cm below the right costal margin. She has no pedal edema.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.3
12.0–16.0


Leukocytes (per mm3)
21,100
4500–11,000


Platelets (per mm3)
68,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.5
0.3–1.0


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
547
100–190


A peripheral-blood smear reveals anisocytosis with numerous teardrop-shaped and nucleated erythrocytes. The leukocyte differential includes 20% neutrophils, 14% bands, 21% metamyelocytes, 17% myelocytes, 3% promyelocytes, and 2% blasts.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests should this patient undergo next?

choices.text: Positron emission tomography/CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splenomegaly, anemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase could suggest an autoimmune hemolytic anemia, but leukoerythroblastosis would not be present. Therefore, a direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is not initially appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral-blood flow cytometry has no diagnostic role in primary myelofibrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis would be useful in diagnosing multiple myeloma, but a patient with multiple myeloma does not typically present with splenomegaly or leukoerythroblastosis.

D) CORRECT:

Primary myelofibrosis is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that results in marrow fibrosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis. A leukoerythroblastic peripheral smear with nucleated erythrocytes, dacryocytes (teardrop-shaped cells), immature myeloid precursors, and occasional circulating blasts is a common finding. Confirming a diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis requires a bone-marrow biopsy, which typically reveals fibrosis that is evident from deposits of reticulin, collagen, or both. The JAK2 V617F mutation is identified in 50% to 60% of patients with primary myelofibrosis. Primary myelofibrosis is a diagnosis of exclusion, so secondary causes of marrow fibrosis or leukoerythroblastosis (e.g., tumors metastatic to the bone marrow, granulomas, and autoimmune conditions) must be ruled out. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) may present with similar features but does not typically demonstrate thrombocytopenia, frequent dacryocytes, or nucleated erythrocytes. Bone-marrow examination can usually distinguish CML from myelofibrosis. However, if there is any doubt about the diagnosis, testing for the BCR-ABL rearrangement should be performed to exclude a diagnosis of CML.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with splenomegaly, anemia, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, nucleated erythrocytes, and immature granulocytes is primary myelofibrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Erythrocytes with a teardrop shape can be seen throughout the image (red overlay). The majority of the erythrocytes appear round and normal.

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, known as dacrocytes, are found in conditions that involve extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly).

E) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography/CT would be helpful in diagnosing certain malignancies, such as lymphoma.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting fevers and chills for the past 4 days. He also notes fatigue and bruising that began about 2 weeks earlier.
He has a history of diet-controlled type 2 diabetes and hypertension but was otherwise previously healthy.
On examination, his temperature is 38.8°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 90/56 mm Hg. He is pale, has dried blood around his nares, and has multiple lower-extremity ecchymoses.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.2
13.5–17.5



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
20,000
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
14,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.8
0.8–1.3


A peripheral-blood smear reveals blasts and other immature cells with purplish granules often obscuring the nucleus. Several cells have rod-like inclusions in the cytoplasm.
Fibrin degradation products, prothrombin time, partial-thromboplastin time, and D-dimer are elevated. Plasma fibrinogen is reduced.
Cytogenetics show the t(15;17) chromosomal translocation in all 20 metaphases.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is characterized by immature lymphocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Myeloblasts are not observed in Hodgkin lymphoma, which often manifests as lymphadenopathy.

C) CORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is characterized by abnormal proliferation and differentiation of myeloid blood cells. The presence of Auer rods indicates a myeloid leukemia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia, a subtype of AML, is frequently characterized by disseminated intravascular coagulation, which is a common cause of morbidity and mortality. Hematologically, patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia present with elevated leukocyte counts with increased promyelocytes in the peripheral blood and bone marrow and purple-colored granules in the cytoplasm.

The chromosomal translocation t(15;17) represents a fusion of the PML and RAR-alpha genes that drives leukemogenesis and is pathognomonic of acute promyelocytic leukemia. This leukemia is very sensitive to the vitamin A derivative all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and to arsenic, both of which contribute to excellent long-term survival. A dangerous complication of treatment with ATRA is the development of differentiation syndrome, characterized by rapid maturation of leukemic cells, sludging of differentiated tumor cells in the lungs, dyspnea, pulmonary infiltrates, fever, capillary leak, edema, and renal failure.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with pancytopenia, Auer rods, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and the chromosomal translocation t(15;17) is acute promyelocytic leukemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Myeloblasts are not observed in non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which often manifests as lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is characterized by immature lymphocytosis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 50-year-old woman reports progressive fatigue over the past several months as well as recent onset of epistaxis and heavy menstrual bleeding. She does not take any medications and denies any recent travel or infection. She drinks one glass of wine each night with dinner. Her family history is negative for blood disorders.
Her vital signs and physical examination are remarkable only for pallor and a resting heart rate of 92 beats per minute.
A complete blood count yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (cells/mm3)
1000
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
18
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
80
22–44


Monocytes (%)
2
4–11


Bands (%)
0
0


Absolute neutrophil count (cells/mm3)
180
1900–7600



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.5
12.0–16.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
101
80–100


Platelet count (cells/mm3)
18,000
150,000–350,000



Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
0.3
0.5–2.5


Vitamin B12 level, prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and fibrinogen level are all within normal limits.
No dysplasia or blasts are noted on peripheral blood smear.
Which one of the following steps is most likely to lead to a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain an ultrasound of the liver and spleen
Transfuse one unit of packed red cells
Initiate a therapeutic trial of a 2-week course of prednisone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A haptoglobin level can be helpful when evaluating for a hemolytic anemia. However, a hemolytic anemia would not be expected to cause pancytopenia, and the patient’s low reticulocyte count is also not consistent with this diagnosis; thus, a haptoglobin level is unlikely to be helpful in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

A screening abdominal ultrasound is unlikely to be useful in this patient. The combination of a negative abdominal examination and normal coagulation studies rules out chronic liver disease or splenomegaly. In addition, these conditions are more likely to cause isolated thrombocytopenia than pancytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of packed red cells is indicated for severe symptomatic anemia, which is not the case here. This patient will eventually require transfusion but not at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid therapy may increase the risk of infection in patients with neutropenia. Although glucocorticoids are often given in conjunction with antithymocyte globulin to reduce the risk of serum sickness, they are not appropriate therapy alone and should not be given without first confirming a diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

The findings of pancytopenia with marked leukopenia and reticulocytopenia in this patient point toward a bone-marrow failure syndrome, such as aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, or paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. The absence of blasts or dysplasia findings on the peripheral blood smear raises the possibility of aplastic anemia, requiring prompt referral and confirmation by bone-marrow biopsy.

Acquired aplastic anemia is a rare condition that affects previously healthy individuals and leads to progressive cytopenias and bone-marrow failure due to an immune response against hematopoietic stem cells. The mean corpuscular volume is commonly elevated at presentation (i.e., macrocytosis) but may also be normal. Typical bone-marrow findings include low overall cellularity on the core biopsy, absence of dysplasia, and normal cytogenetic studies.

Aplastic anemia is considered severe if the patient has bone-marrow cellularity <25%, plus at least two of the following:

• Absolute neutrophil count <500 cells/mm3
• Platelet count <20,000 cells/mm3
• Absolute reticulocyte count <20,000 cells/mm3

Individuals with aplastic anemia require transfusion support and are at risk for severe infection or bleeding secondary to low blood counts. Severe or very severe aplastic anemia is a life-threatening condition requiring therapy. Treatment options include immunosuppressive therapy or, in younger patients, hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation. Standard immunosuppressive therapy consists of antithymocyte globulin and calcineurin inhibition. The addition of eltrombopag has been shown to increase the efficacy of immunosuppressive therapy.

Key learning point: Pancytopenia without peripheral blood smear evidence of dysplasia or circulating blasts in an otherwise healthy individual is suggestive of aplastic anemia, which can be confirmed with bone-marrow biopsy.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is evaluated for having poor growth despite a robust appetite. He has persistently been below the third percentile for height and weight. His parents are healthy, although a maternal uncle recently died of leukemia at 10 years of age and a maternal great-aunt died of breast cancer at a young age.
Physical examination reveals a broad nasal bridge, small eyes with almond-shaped palpebral fissures and epicanthal folds, micrognathia, frontal bossing, and hypopigmented spots on the trunk. His forearms and hands are shown (figure).
A complete blood count yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
2,200,000
4,000,000–5,200,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8
11.5–15.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
52,000
150,000–450,000


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3500
5000–14,500


Neutrophils (%)
56
33–59


Lymphocytes (%)
34
33–50


Monocytes (%)
8
4–11


Eosinophils (%)
1
0–8


Basophils (1%)
1
0–3


A peripheral blood smear reveals no abnormal cells or blasts.
Which one of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen in this case?

choices.text: Large platelets on peripheral blood smear
Microcytic erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disorders of large platelets can be associated with congenital anomalies such as Bernard-Soulier syndrome, gray platelet syndrome, May-Hegglin anomaly, or MYH9-related disorders. However, the clinical features associated with patients who carry such diagnoses are not consistent with those presented in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

The serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level tends to be elevated in patients with Fanconi anemia, even if their liver function is normal. In one study, an elevated AFP level was 100% specific and 93% sensitive for the diagnosis of Fanconi anemia. Thus, a normal or extremely low serum AFP level would be unlikely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress erythropoiesis usually leads to an increase in the size of the erythrocytes or an elevation in mean corpuscular volume (MCV); therefore, microcytic erythrocytes are unlikely in patients with Fanconi anemia. Low MCV is usually seen in conditions such as iron-deficiency anemia or thalassemia syndromes. Patients with thalassemia major who have excessive inefficient erythropoiesis may have frontal bossing and prominent facial bones, but they do not have other facial or skeletal abnormalities, such as the hypoplastic thumbs that are characteristic of Fanconi anemia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has short stature, hypopigmented macules, café au lait spots, hypoplastic thumbs, and the facial features and cytopenias that are characteristic of Fanconi anemia.

Fanconi anemia is an inherited disorder caused by an increased propensity for chromosomal breakage and abnormalities. Affected patients have characteristic congenital abnormalities, progressive bone-marrow failure, and an increased risk of developing myelodysplastic syndromes and leukemia. The disorder is inherited both in an autosomal recessive and X-linked fashion.

Hematologic abnormalities may develop as early as infancy in patients with Fanconi anemia and are present by age 40 in >90% of patients. Thrombocytopenia often precedes anemia and neutropenia, but the progression of bone-marrow failure may vary.

Elevated fetal hemoglobin levels and macrocytosis are often seen in patients with Fanconi anemia and suggest stress hematopoiesis. Diagnostic testing involves analysis of chromosomal breakage induced by diepoxybutane or mitomycin C.

Key learning point: Common laboratory abnormalities associated with Fanconi anemia include thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, macrocytic anemia, and elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein and fetal hemoglobin.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with Fanconi anemia may have kidney abnormalities, such as ectopic or pelvic kidneys. Hydronephrosis or hydroureter may also be present. However, kidney function is usually normal, so the patient’s creatinine level would not be expected to be elevated.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with several bruises on her lower extremities. She has had these bruises for about 6 weeks. The patient has had increasing fatigue and pallor over the past several days. She has a history of recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures treated with carbamazepine. She appears pale and ill. Her pulse is 115/min. There are several subcutaneous purple spots on her legs bilaterally. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2600/mm3, platelet count is 18,000/mm3, and reticulocyte count is 0.3%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP) causes palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy), arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, renal disease, and/or possibly anemia (as a result of gastrointestinal bleeding). Although this patient presents with anemia and petechiae, her thrombocytopenia and lack of other features are inconsistent with HSP.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a syndrome that is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia. Although it is often asymptomatic, it may also manifest with easy bruising or possibly spontaneous petechiae. However, it does not cause pancytopenia or signs of anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common initial symptom of sickle cell disease (SCD) is acute and chronic pain in any body part, which is caused by a vaso-occlusive crisis. Further features include anemia, bone pain, growth retardation, and infections. The onset of SCD is most commonly at 4–5 months of age. Other than anemia, none of these features apply to this adolescent girl.

D) CORRECT:

Certain agents (remember “Can't Make New Blood Cells Properly:” Carbamazepine, Methimazole, NSAIDs, Benzenes, Chloramphenicol, Propylthiouracil) can induce bone marrow failure and subsequent aplastic anemia. Treatment consists of cessation of the causative agent and supportive therapy (i.e., blood or platelet transfusion, treatment of infections).

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) causes thrombocytopenic purpura, neurologic abnormalities, fever, renal disease, and hemolytic anemia. Hematologic findings of TTP include hematuria, schistocytes, decreased Hb, elevated LDH, elevated reticulocytes, and thrombocytopenia. Although this patient presents with pancytopenia and its sequelae, she is much younger than the typical age of onset (approx. 40 years) and does currently not have neurologic abnormalities or renal disease, making TTP very unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's easy bruising, fatigue, and pallor, combined with pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia) and decreased reticulocyte count, indicates aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-week history of fatigue and bruises on her elbows. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with no organomegaly. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2000/mm3, a platelet count of 40,000/mm3, and a reticulocyte count of 0.2%. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. A bone marrow biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Infiltration of collagen and fibrous tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the marrow with collagen and fibrous tissue is seen in conditions such as primary myelofibrosis and hairy cell leukemia. A dry tap is therefore often found on bone marrow aspiration. While both conditions can also present with pancytopenia, patients typically present with hepatosplenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (reticulin stain; intermediate magnification)

The bone marrow is hypercellular (no fat cells left between hematopoietic cells) and shows a remarkable increase in reticulin fibers (stained black). There are several clusters of atypical megakaryocytes (green overlay). The trabecular bone appears thickened/sclerotic (red overlay).

This appearance is characteristic of myelofibrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sheets of abnormal plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy are indicative of multiple myeloma. Although multiple myeloma can also present with pancytopenia and the resulting symptoms, it is typically associated with additional features such as bone pain and hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow specimen (H&E stain)

Plasma cells are large cells that typically have an eccentric nucleus (hatched overlay) with dense, clumped chromatin. The cytoplasm is deeply basophilic due to the abundance of rough endoplasmic reticulum required for the synthesis of antibodies.

C) CORRECT:

Hypocellular bone marrow with prominent fat spaces within (“empty marrow” appearance) is characteristic of aplastic anemia. This condition is most commonly idiopathic but can also be caused by medications (e.g., carbamazepine, NSAIDs), radiation, or viruses (e.g., parvovirus B19), may be inherited (e.g., Fanconi anemia), or occur as a preleukemic condition. Bone marrow biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other important differential diagnoses such as leukemia. Treatment of aplastic anemia involves treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., infection), if identifiable, as well as blood transfusions, immunosuppressive therapy, and hematopoietic cell transplantation.

Key learning point: Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia and a hypocellular bone marrow with increased adipocytes, resulting in an “empty marrow” appearance on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased number of myeloblasts in the bone marrow is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which would occur among adults and can cause anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, a CBC in patients with AML would usually show an increased total leukocyte count due to the presence of myeloblasts in peripheral blood.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear (Wright-Giemsa stain, high magnification)

Promyelocytes with azurophilic granules can be seen as well as a myeloblast containing multiple violet, rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, known as Auer rods (examples indicated by yellow lines).

Auer rods are typically seen in certain types of acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., APL) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypercellular, dysplastic bone marrow with ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow biopsy is found in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). Although MDS can also present with pancytopenia, it usually affects elderly patients or occurs secondary to an underlying condition (e.g., cytostatic therapy) and is often associated with hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, in contrast to this patient's condition, MDS usually progresses slowly.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of blood cells from a bone marrow sample (Prussian blue stain)

Image shows numerous mature and immature erythrocytes. Some of the immature RBCs feature round, basophilic inclusions (iron deposits; arrowhead) within their mitochondria (which mostly surround the nuclei). These cells are called sideroblasts (red overlay).

Sideroblasts are found in various diseases such as sideroblastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, and sickle cell disease.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory findings (i.e., fatigue due to anemia, bruising due to thrombocytopenia, and leukocytopenia) indicate pancytopenia with a decreased reticulocyte count. In the absence of splenomegaly, these findings indicate aplastic anemia.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue and scattered bruises on her arms. She has experienced several episodes of nosebleeds over the past month. Physical examination shows pallor and petechiae on her lower extremities, but no splenomegaly. Her vital signs are normal (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
78 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


MCV
90 fL
80 - 95 fL


WBC
2.0 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Platelet count
16 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Reticulocyte
0.1%
0.2 - 1.2%



Bone marrow biopsy: Pending result
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) typically presents with a hypercellular marrow filled with lymphoblasts, often with lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. The absence of splenomegaly and the presence of pancytopenia with a low reticulocyte count suggest marrow failure rather than a proliferative disorder like ALL.

B) CORRECT:

Aplastic anemia manifests with pancytopenia, characterized by fatigue, easy bruising, and mucosal bleeding due to low hemoglobin, platelet, and white blood cell counts. The decreased reticulocyte count indicates a hypoproliferative bone marrow, suggesting bone marrow failure. This condition results from diminished or destroyed hematopoietic stem cells, often due to immune-mediated destruction or toxic exposure. The pending bone marrow biopsy is expected to show hypocellularity with fatty infiltration, confirming the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia and normocytic anemia due to bone marrow failure, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and petechial hemorrhages.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia with normal red and white cell production. The presence of pancytopenia and a low reticulocyte count in this patient indicates a global marrow pathology, inconsistent with the peripheral platelet destruction seen in ITP.

D) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) typically affects older adults and presents with dysplastic features on peripheral smear or bone marrow examination, often with mild macrocytosis. The patient's age and the absence of dysplastic features or macrocytosis make MDS unlikely. The extremely low reticulocyte count suggests marrow failure rather than the ineffective hematopoiesis seen in MDS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressive daytime sleepiness and exertional dyspnea. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor and several pinpoint, purple spots on his legs. His hemoglobin is 85 g/L (125–170), white blood cell count is 3.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count is 16 × 109/L (130–380). A peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. Which one of the following laboratory values is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is a marker of cell breakdown. The combination of pancytopenia and increased LDH may be seen in conditions such as paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria or hematological malignancy (e.g., acute leukemia). However, these conditions typically also manifest with abnormal blood smear findings, such as signs of hemolysis (e.g., schistocytes) or malignancy (e.g., blast cells).

B) CORRECT:

Clinical findings of fatigue, pallor, and petechiae (pinpoint, purple spots), together with laboratory results showing pancytopenia, are consistent with aplastic anemia. In patients with aplastic anemia, peripheral blood smear typically shows normocytosis or mild macrocytosis. An increase in erythropoietin (EPO) production (hypoxia-induced EPO expression) is a physiological response to anemia, as EPO stimulates erythropoiesis. Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure, which has a variety of causes, such as viruses, medication side effects, congenital etiologies, radiation, and toxins; > 50% of cases are idiopathic.

Key learning point: Erythropoietin levels increase in response to anemia as a compensatory mechanism, even when bone marrow failure such as aplastic anemia prevents effective red blood cell production.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated homocysteine concentrations may be seen in vitamin B12 deficiency or folate deficiency. A deficiency of these vitamins can cause megaloblastic anemia and may even lead to pancytopenia. However, peripheral blood smear in patients with megaloblastic anemia typically shows macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils, not normochromic, normocytic cells.

D) INCORRECT:

The reticulocyte count can serve as a marker of effective erythropoiesis. An elevated reticulocyte count may be seen in cases of increased RBC breakdown or loss. As this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia, in which bone marrow activity is drastically reduced, his reticulocyte count would be decreased rather than increased.

E) INCORRECT:

Transferrin concentration varies inversely to iron stores and is therefore increased in patients with iron deficiency anemia. This patient's peripheral blood smear shows no features of iron deficiency (e.g., microcytosis, hypochromasia). In addition, pancytopenia cannot be explained by iron deficiency alone. Instead, this patient's presentation is concerning for aplastic anemia in which iron stores, and thus transferrin concentrations, are typically normal. In some cases of aplastic anemia, iron stores may even be increased (due to lack of use) and transferrin levels decreased accordingly.
questions.hint: A bone marrow biopsy of this patient would most likely show hypocellular, fat-filled bone marrow, consistent with aplastic anemia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of a 5-day history of fever, fatigue, and red spots on her body. Her temperature is 38.3°C, pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. On examination, she has pallor, petechiae, and a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 70 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count of 2.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), platelet count of 40 × 109/L (130–380), and reticulocyte count of 0.2% (0.5%–1.5%). Peripheral blood smear shows normochromic, normocytic cells. Bone marrow aspirate reveals hypocellularity. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary myelofibrosis is a condition that is very rare in childhood, with a peak incidence between the 6th–7th decades. Labs can demonstrate pancytopenia and bone marrow hypocellularity, but the condition is chronic in nature and is often accompanied by splenomegaly. A peripheral smear would demonstrate nucleated erythrocyte precursors and immature myeloid cells. This young patient has both a different clinical course and a peripheral smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), occurring most commonly in children aged 2–5 years, manifests with hepatosplenomegaly and B symptoms. Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hyperleukocytosis are common laboratory abnormalities and peripheral smear typically shows granulocyte precursors and nucleated erythrocytes. Bone marrow aspirate would show hypercellularity owing to neoplastic invasion, not hypocellularity as seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Aplastic anemia is the cause of this patient's pancytopenia, normocytic anemia, and hypocellularity on bone marrow aspirate. Viral infections, either idiopathic (i.e., nontypeable or unknown virus, as in this case), EBV, or CMV are known to cause aplastic anemia in otherwise healthy children. Noninfectious causes include drugs (e.g., chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, or benzene), prior radiation, congenital conditions (e.g., Fanconi anemia or Shwachman-Diamond syndrome), and complications of leukemia. Parvovirus B19 may also cause pure red cell aplasia or aplastic crisis, but these primarily occur in patients with immunodeficiency or chronic hemolytic anemias, respectively.

Key learning point: Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia, normocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count, and hypocellular bone marrow, often following viral infections or exposure to drugs, toxins, or radiation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

The marrow is hypocellular and shows fatty replacement.

These findings indicate aplastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an autoimmune disease targeting platelets, which results in thrombocytopenia and causes bleeding manifestations. In ITP, there are normal RBC and leukocyte counts, normochromic and normocytic cells on peripheral smear, and normal bone marrow findings. This patient's pancytopenia and hypocellular marrow would be inconsistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma classically manifests with signs of hypercalcemia (e.g., abdominal pain), renal impairment, anemia (e.g., shortness of breath, fatigue, or pallor), and bony lesions (CRAB criteria). Peripheral smear characteristically shows rouleaux formations, and marrow aspiration demonstrates abnormal populations of plasma cells. This condition is virtually unheard of in children, with a peak incidence in the 6th decade.
questions.hint: This patient's history of acute fever, fatigue, and maculopapular rash is suggestive of a viral infection. Her lab values demonstrating pancytopenia in conjunction with a decreased reticulocyte count, normal peripheral smear, and bone marrow hypocellularity all likely stem from this infection.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to your clinic with several bruises on her lower extremities that have been present for about 6 weeks. She reports increasing fatigue and pallor over the past several days. She has a history of recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures and is being treated with carbamazepine. On examination, she appears pale and ill. Her pulse is 115/min. There are several subcutaneous purple spots on both legs. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin concentration of 84 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count of 2.6 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), platelet count of 18 × 109/L (130–380), and reticulocyte count of 0.3% (0.5%–1.5%). Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP) causes palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy), arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, renal disease, and/or possibly anemia (as a result of gastrointestinal bleeding). Although this patient presents with anemia and petechiae, her thrombocytopenia and lack of other features are inconsistent with HSP.

B) INCORRECT:

The most common initial symptom of sickle cell disease (SCD) is acute and chronic pain in any body part, which is caused by a vaso-occlusive crisis. Further features include anemia, bone pain, growth retardation, and infections. The onset of SCD is most commonly at 4–5 months of age. Other than anemia, none of these features apply to this adolescent girl.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a syndrome that is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia. Although it is often asymptomatic, it may also manifest with easy bruising or possibly spontaneous petechiae. However, it does not cause pancytopenia or signs of anemia.

D) CORRECT:

Certain agents (remember “Can't Make New Blood Cells Properly:” Carbamazepine, Methimazole, NSAIDs, Benzenes, Chloramphenicol, Propylthiouracil) can induce bone marrow failure and subsequent aplastic anemia. Treatment consists of cessation of the causative agent and supportive therapy (i.e., blood or platelet transfusion, treatment of infections).

Key learning point: Certain medications, such as carbamazepine, can cause drug-induced aplastic anemia by suppressing bone marrow and leading to pancytopenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) causes thrombocytopenic purpura, neurologic abnormalities, fever, renal disease, and hemolytic anemia. Hematologic findings of TTP include hematuria, schistocytes, decreased Hb, elevated LDH, elevated reticulocytes, and thrombocytopenia. Although this patient presents with pancytopenia and its sequelae, she is much younger than the typical age of onset (approx. 40 years) and does currently not have neurologic abnormalities or renal disease, making TTP very unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's easy bruising, fatigue, and pallor, combined with pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia) and decreased reticulocyte count, indicates aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of fatigue, shortness of breath, and spontaneous bruising. He has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Physical examination shows pallor, scattered petechiae, and no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 6.8 g/dL, white blood cell count 1,200/μL, platelet count 28,000/μL, and reticulocyte count 0.5%. The peripheral blood smear shows no blasts or dysplastic cells. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is useful for detecting hematologic malignancies and inherited bone marrow failure syndromes. However, with no blasts or abnormal cells on peripheral smear, another initial diagnostic step is more appropriate to evaluate marrow cellularity and architecture.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Bone marrow biopsy is the most appropriate next step for this patient with unexplained pancytopenia. The absence of blasts, dysplastic cells, and organomegaly along with a low reticulocyte count suggests impaired bone marrow production. Bone marrow biopsy will help differentiate between aplastic anemia (hypocellular marrow with fat spaces) and other causes of bone marrow failure, such as myelodysplastic syndrome or marrow infiltration.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics are indicated for neutropenic fever when the absolute neutrophil count (ANC) is < 500/μL or expected to decrease to this level within 48 hours. This patient is afebrile and has ANC > 500/μL. Another step in management is indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) stimulates granulocyte precursors and promotes bone marrow recovery in neutropenia. G-CSF is typically used for treatment-related neutropenia or chronic neutropenia with established diagnoses. The underlying cause of this patient's pancytopenia must first be determined.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency can cause pancytopenia with megaloblastic changes on peripheral smear. However, this patient's blood smear shows no megaloblastic changes, making nutritional deficiencies less likely as the primary cause.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue and new-onset mild abdominal pain. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 98; R, 15; T, 38.3°C (100.9°F). Physical examination shows mild splenomegaly and scattered petechiae. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 7.8 g/dL, platelets 22,000/mcL, and absolute neutrophil count (ANC) 420/mcL. The patient reports no recent travel, medication changes, or sick contacts. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Without active bleeding, platelet transfusion is not urgently indicated for moderate thrombocytopenia (20,000–70,000/mcL). Another management step is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor therapy may be considered in neutropenia management but requires hematology guidance and is not the immediate priority in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is part of the diagnostic workup for pancytopenia, but another more urgent step in management is indicated first.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has fever with severe neutropenia (ANC < 500/mcL), which constitutes neutropenic fever requiring urgent empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Temperature elevation in neutropenic patients can indicate life-threatening infection and requires immediate antibiotic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

While hemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL represents significant anemia, red blood cell transfusion is not the most urgent intervention in this patient.
